Airline partnerships often generate headlines about ‚Äúmergers,‚Äù ‚Äúalliances,‚Äù and ‚Äúintegrations,‚Äù yet these terms describe very different legal and operational realities. This brief explainer clarifies the distinction and outlines how the National Mediation Board (NMB) evaluates when two carriers effectively operate as one for labor-representation purposes.

üîπ What Is an Integration?

An integration occurs when two airlines coordinate certain aspects of their operations without changing corporate ownership. Examples include:

  • Reciprocal frequent-flyer or loyalty-program benefits
  • Shared airport facilities, gates, or terminals
  • Joint scheduling systems or interline booking
  • Marketing alliances and reciprocal flight codes

Integrations are designed to improve efficiency and connectivity but leave each company legally distinct. They may still require review by the Department of Transportation (DOT) or Department of Justice (DOJ) if the collaboration affects competition or market access.

üîπ What Is a Merger?

A merger is a formal corporate transaction in which one airline combines with another through the exchange of stock, assets, and management control. Following regulatory clearance, a single entity remains.

Mergers are typically disclosed through SEC filings such as 8-K reports or proxy statements and undergo antitrust review by the DOJ Antitrust Division and DOT to ensure fair competition and consumer protection.

üîπ What Triggers a Single-Carrier Determination?

Under the Railway Labor Act (RLA), the NMB may determine that two or more carriers operate as a single transportation system even when no legal merger has occurred. The Board looks at the functional reality of how the airlines operate day-to-day. Common factors include:

  • Unified management or common officers directing labor relations
  • Shared payroll, personnel, or benefits administration
  • Integrated scheduling, dispatch, or crew-assignment systems
  • Joint branding, marketing, or route coordination suggesting a single operation
  • Centralized control of key business or safety functions

When these elements show that employees effectively work within one system, the NMB can issue a Single-Carrier Determination. Such a decision consolidates labor-representation coverage across the combined system.

üîπ Why a Single-Carrier Finding Matters

Although uncommon, the NMB can issue a single-carrier finding without a formal merger. This triggers important procedural questions under the RLA: which union, if any, represents the newly combined group of employees, and whether a new election should be conducted.

The process is entirely separate from corporate or antitrust law‚Äîit concerns representation rights, not business structure. Understanding this distinction helps aviation professionals interpret partnership and integration news with greater accuracy.
